case_name: M/s. Kirloskar Oil Engines Limited v. Bibawe

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 523 of 1961 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 523 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the award dated September 2,

facts.text: Appeal is from the award dated September 2, 1960 of the Industrial Tribunal Maharashtra at Bombay in Complaint I.T. No. 38 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated September 2, 1960, of the Industrial Tribunal Maharashtra at Bombay in Complaint  I. T.  No. 38 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on July 31, 1962 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. July 31. The Judgment of the companyrt was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The respondent Bibawe made an applic

facts.text: Respondent Bibawe made an application to the Industrial Tribunal at Bombay under s. 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Bibawe made an application to the Industrial Tribunal at Bombay under a, 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. He alleged that be had been employed by the appellant M

facts.text: Bibawe alleged he had been employed by M/s. Kirloskar Oil Engines, Limited as a watchman since July 21, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: s. 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. He alleged that be had been employed by the appellant M s. Kirloskar Oil Engines, Limited, as a watchman since July 21, 1958, and that he

facts.text: Bibawe had become a permanent workman of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: since July 21, 1958, and that he bad been working as such watchman with the appellant and had become its permanent workman.

facts.text: On May 15, 1960, the Security Officer of the appellant Company intimated to Bibawe that he had been discharged from service with effect from that date.

anchor.surface_text: On May 15,1960, the Security Officer of the appellant Company intimated to him that he had been discharged from service with effect from that date.

facts.text: At the time of discharge, an industrial dispute was pending between the appellant and its employees before an Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent urged that at the time when this order of discharge was orally served on him, an industrial dispute was pending between the appellant and its employees before an Industrial Tribunal

facts.text: Appellant denied that the respondent was its employee.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied that the respondent was its employee. It pleaded that the respondents services had been made available to the appellant by an arrangement,

facts.text: Respondent's services made available to appellant by an arrangement where he was not the employee of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It pleaded that the respondents services had been made available to the appellant by an arrangement, the terms of which clearly indicated that even whilst the respondent was working as a watchman

facts.text: Tribunal held that s.33 was contravened and ordered reinstatement of respondent with full back wages from date of discharge.

anchor.surface_text: even so in substance the Tribunal seems to have taken the view that s.33 had been companytravened by the appellant and so an order has been passed directing the appellant to reinstate the respondent with full back wages from the date of his discharge.

facts.text: Scheme evolved by police department to supply watchmen to different employers.

anchor.surface_text: Turning to the scheme under which the respondent was asked to do the work as a watchman by the appellant, most of its material terms emphatically bring out the fact that the respondent cannot

facts.text: Private person applies to District Superintendent of Police for watchman services.

anchor.surface_text: The private person who require the services of watchman have to apply to the District Superintendent of Police. The District Superintendent of Police supplies a watchman if he thinks a suitable watchman is available.

facts.text: Pay of watchman recovered per month in advance from employer and credited to Watchman Fund.

anchor.surface_text: The amount on account of pay of the watchman is recovered per month in advance from the employer. This amount has to be credited to the Watchman Fund on receipt of advance bills submitted from the office

facts.text: Out of amount recovered, Rs.5/8/- per month deducted for clothing, balance paid to watchman.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the amount thus recovered from the employer Rs.5/8/- per month are deducted on account of the companyt of clothing supplied and the balance is paid to the watchman.

facts.text: I.G.P. authorised to vary rate up to Rs. 30/- per annum.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the I.O.P. is authorised to vary this rate in any district under his companytrol subject to the maximum of Rs. 30/- per annum.

facts.text: Work supervised by subordinate police, night patrols.

anchor.surface_text: The work done by the watchman is super- vised by the subordinate police, particularly at night by the night patrols who know where police watchmen are employed and look them up to see if they are alert.

facts.text: Watchmen mustered for duty in police section, paid by Superintendent of Police like ordinary police.

anchor.surface_text: The men thus sent as watchmen are mustered for duty in the police section in which their employers bungalows are situated. They are paid by the Superintendent of Police direct like ordinary police.

facts.text: Watchmen under departmental control of Superintendent of Police, who can fine or punish them; employers not authorised.

anchor.surface_text: They are entirely under the departmental companytrol and orders of Superintendent of Police and he alone can fine or punish them the employers are number authorised to do so.

facts.text: Employer to give fortnight's notice to dispense with watchman.

anchor.surface_text: An employer is requested to give a fortnights numberice in case he wants to dispense with the service of the watchman.

facts.text: Court holds respondent not employee of appellant based on scheme terms.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion having regard to these terms of the scheme it is difficult to accept the view taken by the Tribunal that the respondent was an employee of the appellant, that he was an industrial

facts.text: Respondent took uniform from Police Office.

anchor.surface_text: He admitted that after he was selected he was instructed by the appellant to go the Police Office and take uniform so that he took the uniform from the Police Office.

facts.text: Leave sanctioned by police office.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chorpade stated that leave is sanctioned by the police office though be added that if the watchman wants casual leave he sometimes makes application through the employer or direct to the office,

facts.text: Police Jamadar took watchmen to gate of Kirloskar Company.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent admitted that he and the other watchmen were taken to the gate of Kirloskar Company by Police Jamadar when they were interviewed

facts.text: Mr. Pansare enquired once or twice a month about quality of watchmen's work.

anchor.surface_text: he admitted that Mr. Pansare came once or twice a month and enquired with the management about the quality of the work of the watchmen.

arguments.claim: Proper test for employer-employee relationship depends on all facts and circumstances; no single test like control is decisive in every case.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion as Lord Porter himself has observed the decision of the question as to the relationship of employer and employee must be determined in the light of all relevant facts and circumstances and it would number be expedient to lay down any particular test as decisive in the matter.
